title-group.article-title: Two-phase anaerobic digestion of the organic fraction of municipal solid waste: estimation of methane production

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Sanitary Engineering, Mahidol University, and Centre for Environmental Health, Toxicology and Management of Chemicals (ETM), Ratchathevee, Bangkok, Thailand
2Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, University of Auckland, Auckland, New Zealand
3Department of Civil and Natural Resources Engineering, University of Canterbury, Christchurch, New Zealand

author-notes.corresp: Panagiotis Elefsiniotis, Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, University of Auckland, Private Bag 92019, Auckland, New Zealand Email: t.elefsiniotis@auckland.ac.nz

abstract.p:
Energy generation from methane (CH4) is one of the primary targets of the anaerobic digestion process. Consequently, the focus of this study was to investigate the effect on CH4 production of total solids (TS) loading (measured as % TS) and hydraulic residence time (HRT) during the treatment of the organic fraction of municipal solid waste (OFMSW). Laboratory-scale, two-phase anaerobic digestion systems were employed with each system consisting of an acidogenic reactor and a methanogenic reactor linked in series. The group A runs in the experiment explored the effect on digester performance of four variations in methanogenic HRT (15, 20, 25 and 30 days) at three different feed TS concentrations (8, 12 and 15%). The group B runs compared the actual methane yield (0.14 to 0.45 L g
VS
feed
− 1
) to that predicted by the Chen–Hashimoto model. Results from the group A runs indicated that acidogenesis improved with an increase in % TS and a decrease in HRT; while, methanogenesis behaved inversely, achieving higher yields at the lower % TS and longer HRT values. In comparison with the group B runs, the Chen–Hashimoto model under-predicted (by an average of 16.5 ± 6.6%) the CH4 yield obtained from the digestion of OFMSW.

kwd-group.kwd: Organic fraction of municipal solid waste

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The organic fraction of municipal solid waste (OFMSW) consists mainly of food, paper, garden, and other organic wastes (e.g. plastics). From a weight perspective, it is estimated that 50 to 80% of municipal solid waste is organic (Macias-Corral et al., 2008; Nguyen et al., 2007; Papachristou et al., 2009); while 75% is the normal figure quoted for the biodegradable fraction (Gomes et al., 2008). Reducing the biodegradable fraction via anaerobic digestion is the focus of much research, not only because of waste volume minimization, but also because of the recovery of the energy in the form of biogas (Demirbas, 2006; Kumar et al., 2009; Rao et al., 2000). For example, Fongsatitkul et al. (2010) has estimated that 21 500 tonnes day−1 of Thailand’s municipal solid waste could be digested to biogas. Since methane (CH4) is the principal component of biogas (at 65%) and has an energy content of 39 MJ m−3 (WEF, 2003); a clear driver exists to investigate using OFMSW as an energy source. In particular, Thailand’s electrical energy consumption is 5.4 × 108 GJ year−1 (Ministry of Energy, 2007); thus, the energy released from the digestion of OFMSW could supply approximately 17% (not accounting for energy losses) of Thailand’s electricity needs.

The anaerobic digestion process can be optimized to handle input material; however, careful attention needs to be paid to specific indicators of stability (i.e. pH and alkalinity) as well as process performance [i.e. volatile solids (VS) reduction, volatile fatty acid (VFA) production and CH4 generation]. From a biochemical perspective, the latter three indicators are interconnected since VFA production and gas generation are by-products of the first parameter, while VFA production is a precursor to the third. To enhance anaerobic performance, the majority of digester systems are operated in the mesophilic range (Bolzonella et al., 2005, Capela et al., 2008, Fernández et al., 2008). At such temperatures (35 to 38 °C), CH4 yields for the OFMSW are generally in the range of 0.18 to 0.43 L g
VS
feed
− 1
(Gunaseelan, 1997; Hartmann and Ahring, 2005).

Many researchers have investigated a variety of operational parameters to increase the CH4 yield. These include pH (Liu et al., 2008); temperature (Komemoto et al., 2009; Rahman and Elefsiniotis, 2010); organic loading (Najafpour et al., 2006; Rincón et al., 2007), retention time (Feng et al., 2009; Fongsatitkul et al., 2010), and inhibitory compounds (Chen et al., 2008; Pavlostathis and Maeng, 2000). In addition, it has been documented that phase-separation can improve the overall efficiency of the process, especially under high organic loading conditions (Bouallagui et al., 2004; Pavan et al., 2000). Overall, two specific design parameters that have strong potential to influence CH4 generation are total solids (TS) loading (measured as % TS) and hydraulic retention time (HRT). The research described in this paper therefore explores the digestion of OFMSW at various % TS concentrations and selected HRTs. The effect of these two operational parameters is measured by examining their influence on VS destruction and gas production. In the latter case, the actual yields and stoichiometric methane estimations were compared to the Chen–Hashimoto model (Chen and Hashimoto, 1978) predictions expected at specific values of % TS and HRT.

sec.title: Reactor set-up, operation and experimental design
sec.p: A laboratory-scale, two-phase, mesophilic anaerobic digestion system was used to examine the digestability of OFMSW collected from the Integrated Solid Waste Management Center (ISWMC) located in the city of Chonburi, Thailand. The digestion system consisted of four acidogenic reactors, each with an active volume of 1.8 L, and four methanogenic reactors, each with an active volume of 12 L. In order for the four systems to operate simultaneously, each acidogenic-methanogenic couple was linked in series. A typical example of a coupled system is shown in Figure 1. The acid-phase digesters were operated at ambient temperature (29 ± 1 °C), while the methane-phase digesters were heated to 35 °C. Both reactors were completely mixed reactors without recycle; therefore the HRT was equivalent to the solids retention time (SRT).

caption.p: Schematic drawing of a typical experimental unit: A, acidogenic reactor; M, methanogenic reactor; 1, influent to A; 2, effluent from A; 3, feeder to M; 4, effluent from M; 5, heater; 6, gas meter.

sec.p: The experiment was divided into two groups (A and B), with group A consisting of three runs (1 to 3) and group B consisting of two runs (4 and 5). Each run was operated for approximately 6 to 8 weeks with the purpose of the group A runs being to evaluate the digester performance, as well as to determine the kinetic coefficients associated with the Chen–Hashimoto model. Group B was a predictive set of runs, to which the model was compared in terms of methane yield.

More comprehensively, runs 1 to 3 (group A) explored the effect of four variations in methanogenic HRT (15, 20, 25 and 30 days) at three different total solids (TS) concentrations (8, 12 and 15%) (i.e. each run was associated with a separate % TS). In group B, run 4 focused on an 8% TS concentration at three methanogenic HRTs (i.e. 20, 25 and 30 days), while run 5 used three different % TS concentrations (8, 12 and 15%) at a 25 day methanogenic HRT. As mentioned, runs 4 and 5 used the Chen–Hashimoto coefficients obtained from runs 1 to 3, to first predict the methane yield and then compare it to the actual methane generated from runs 4 and 5. A summary table of the experimental design is shown in Table 1.

sec.title: Origin of seed and waste
sec.p: The anaerobic seed for the experiments was obtained from the Nuang Kham municipal wastewater treatment plant in Bangkok, Thailand, while the organic fraction of the solid waste was obtained after manual removal of inorganic material at the ISWMC center, Chonburi, Thailand. The latter strategy was deliberate and expected to maximize the potential of biogas production during digestion. Upon arrival at the laboratory, the waste was homogenized by grinding before being diluted with tap water in three 50 L capacity storage tanks to the target % TS concentration of 8, 12 or 15%. The waste was then stored at 4 °C until used. Relevant parameters are listed in Table 2 and it was noted that the VS/TS ratio in the OFMSW was 0.85 reflecting the separation strategy followed at the ISWMC center.

caption.p: Influent characteristics of OFMSW and seed.

sec.title: Sampling schedule and analytical methods
sec.p: Throughout this study, influent and final effluent samples were collected from each digestion system three times a week and analyzed for TS and VS, while the effluent from the methane-phase digester was further analyzed for pH, alkalinity, VFAs and CH4 production. In addition, pH, alkalinity, and VFAs were also measured from the effluent of the acid-phase reactor. Finally, the total organic carbon (TOC) and total Kjeldahl nitrogen (TKN) were measured sporadically on the OFMSW. Analytical determinations for TS, VS, alkalinity, TOC and TKN were conducted in accordance with standard methods (APHA, 2005) while commercially-available glass electrodes were used for pH. In particular, TOC was determined by the high-temperature combustion method using a Shimadzu TOC – 500 analyzer; gas production was measured by the water displacement method; while gas composition and total VFAs were determined by a gas chromatograph (Agilent 6890N) equipped with a flame-ionization detector and capillary column (INNOWAX 19095N). Further details of all analytical procedures can be found elsewhere (Padungthon, 2005).

sec.title: Chen–Hashimoto methane production model development
sec.p: The Chen–Hashimoto model (Chen and Hashimoto, 1978; 1980) is a modification of the Contois model (Contois, 1959; Hu et al., 2002; Vavilin et al., 2001). This model is based on fundamental biochemical principles and has been found to be a reliable predictive tool in applications regarding digestion of wastes with substantial TS content, including OFMSW (Cecchi et al., 1990; Jiménez et al., 2006). It has the following form:

where S is the effluent substrate concentration (mg L−1); So is the influent substrate concentration (mg L−1); θ is the hydraulic retention time (day); k is the dimensionless kinetic constant; µmax is the maximum specific growth rate of micro-organisms (day−1).

In anaerobic digestion, the substrate (COD, BOD5, VS, etc.) is commonly represented as substrate utilization and thus can be effectively expressed in terms of methane production. Therefore, the Chen–Hashimoto model can be transposed to the following:

where Yo is the theoretical maximum methane yield at STP (LCH4 g
VS
feed
− 1
); Y is the actual methane yield at STP (LCH4 g
VS
feed
− 1
).

The value for Yo represents the maximum volume of methane that could be achieved at an infinite retention time (θ∞) (i.e. the amount of methane generated under complete biodegradation). Yo can therefore be obtained from a plot of 1/θ versus Y and, as θ → ∞, Yo becomes the intercept on the vertical axis. If θ is the HRT of the methanogenic reactor (θmeth), then Equation (2) can be manipulated to:

where plotting θmeth against
Y
Y o
− Y
will yield the kinetic parameters µmax and k.

The daily methane production rate (δ) on a volumetric basis (LCH4
L
RCTR
− 1
) is determined by multiplying Equation (2) by the loading rate (So/θmeth) with appropriate manipulation, arriving at:

Finally, Equation (5) (the maximum methane volumetric production rate (δmax)) is arrived at by taking the derivative of Equation (4) with respect to θmeth and equating it to zero under the understanding that washout of the micro-organisms occurs at the minimum hydraulic retention time (θmin), the reciprocal of µmax.

sec.title: Effect of HRT and TS concentration on acidogenesis
sec.p: As indicated in Table 1, group A had three runs with each run occurring at a specific TS concentration (i.e. 8, 12 or 15%). The performance parameters for these runs have been summarized in Table 3, on an acidogenic HRT (θacid) basis (i.e. 2.25, 3.0, 3.75 and 4.5 days).

caption.p: Performance parameters for the acidogenic reactors.

sec.p: Firstly, the pH data in all reactors indicated a suitable environment for acidogenesis, with the overall trend being a slight increase in pH with increasing HRT. In general, the pH was considerably lower than most acid-phase digesters reported in the literature, which normally operate in the range of 4.8 to 5.8 (Oktem et al., 2006; Zhu et al., 2009). The performance of the system as measured by total VFA production did not appear however to suffer from the low pH obtained in the acidogenic digesters. As the HRT lengthened, VFA production dropped significantly; however the pH was too low to attribute loss of VFAs to methanogenic activity (Liu et al., 2008). It is suggested therefore that the decrease in VFA production may be the result of conversion of organic matter to non-VFA C1 to C4 end-products, such as formic and lactic acids, and/or alcohols, aldehydes and ketones (Elefsiniotis and Oldham, 1994; Lü et al., 2008). Alternatively, other soluble metabolic intermediates could be generated during the digestion process (Aquino and Stuckey 2008; Elefsiniotis et al., 2004).

It is also clear from Table 3 that, across the board, VFA production increased with an increase in % TS, a reflection of the greater amount of solids available for conversion to VFAs. Finally, the VFA/alkalinity range of 0.30 to 0.63 indicates a stable system since it is within the range (0.20 to 0.80) quoted in the literature for acid-phase digesters (Demirel and Yenigun, 2004). It is noted that the shorter HRTs are at the higher end of this range.

sec.title: Effect of HRT and TS concentration on methanogenesis
sec.p: Table 1 also indicates that group A had three runs each at the methanogenic HRTs (θmeth) of 15, 20, 25 and 30 days. Again, each run occurred at three TS concentrations (i.e. 8, 12 and 15%). The results are shown in Table 4 as a function of HRTmeth. The pH data in most of the methanogic reactors was slightly alkaline with a mean value of 7.22 ± 0.26. The pH trend revealed that the lowest value of 6.8 occurred at the shortest HRT (15 days), with the most significant increase in pH (approximately 0.4 pH units) occurring between the HRTs of 20 and 25 days. This was independent of solids concentration. The low pH values associated with the shortest methanogenic HRT could be linked to the large amount of VFAs entering the methanogenic reactors from the preceding acidogenic reactors (Table 3). The data in Table 4 indicates a significant drop in alkalinity as the HRT lengthened, while within a particular HRT, the alkalinity increased as the % TS increased. It is suspected that the increasing buffering capacity with increasing % TS could be attributed to an increase in ammonia concentration, as a greater amount of VS became available for degradation at the higher % TS (Forster-Carneiro et al., 2008).

caption.p: Performance parameters for the methanogenic reactor.

sec.p: In general, anaerobic digestion studies treating municipal wastewaters normally have VS removals in the range of 40 to 60% (Huyard et al., 2000; Park et al., 2006). The percentage TS and VS removals for each run in Table 4 are relatively larger than this range implying that OFMSW is particularly amenable to anaerobic degradation. In particular, it reflects the advantage practised in this research of strategically removing the inorganic fraction from the municipal solid waste prior to anaerobic digestion. The percentage TS and VS removals exhibited an improvement as the length of the HRT increased; while at each HRT, there was a slight reduction in either the TS or VS removal as the % TS in the influent increased. This drop was most pronounced at the lowest HRT which may denote stress due to solids overloading (McMahon et al., 2004).

sec.title: Methane yield and predictions from stoichiometry
sec.p: Table 5 indicates that all combinations of HRTmeth and % TS produced a methane yield within the range quoted earlier. In addition, the yield substantially improved as the HRT lengthened indicating that the longer HRTs provided more time for solids conversion. That is, VFAs entering a methane-phase from an acid-phase reactor need sufficient time to be converted to CH4; and, at the shorter HRTs, this time was simply not available resulting in lower CH4 production. The CH4 yield also showed a significant decrease as the TS increased from 8 to 15%, indicating impairment of the gas production capability. This again may be linked to organic overloading (Angelidaki et al., 2006; Maroun and El Fadel, 2007; Rahman and Elefsiniotis, 2010) and is suggested by the observable (although minor) drop in % TS and % VS removal with increasing % TS feed concentration (Table 4). In summary, the longest methanogenic HRT studied (i.e. 30 days), at the smallest % TS loading (i.e. 8%) yielded the best performance overall in terms of percentage TS and VS removals as well as CH4 yield.

caption.p: Methane yield and actual to stoichiometric CH4 yield ratio.

sec.p: Based on the formula C50H85O40N2 for OFMSW (Liwarska-Bizukojc and Ledakowicz, 2003), the theoretical specific methane production can be calculated for each reactor in each run. A balanced equation following the approach put forward by Sawyer et al. (2003) was developed as shown here:

The hydrogen term in Equation (6) indicates the need for an external energy source to complete the conversion of the organic matter to CH4 and CO2 (Bregnard et al., 1997; Sawyer et al., 2003). The VS concentration in the feed (Table 2) was used in conjunction with Equation (6) to calculate the theoretical CH4 yield which was 0.50 L g
VS
feed
− 1
at standard temperature and pressure. Taking into account the actual yield, the corresponding ratios of actual to theoretical stoichiometric values were determined and these are also depicted in Table 5. As is evident, as the HRTmeth increased, the ratio approached the stoichiometric limit, again indicating that longer HRTs provide more time for conversion of organic matter to CH4. In all cases however, overloading caused by an increase in % TS triggered a decline in CH4 production as indicated by the lower ratios achieved.

sec.title: Kinetic parameter analysis and predictive modelling
sec.p:
As mentioned above (sub-section entitled ‘Chen-Hashimoto methane production model development’), the Yo values can be extracted graphically as vertical intercepts from a plot of 1/θ versus Y, as θ → ∞. Thus, the CH4 yield (i.e. Y values) from Table 5 were used to find Yo values of 0.656, 0.663 and 0.586 (L g
VS
feed
− 1
) for the % TS concentrations of 8, 12 and 15%, respectively. Equation (3) was then used to obtain values of µmax and k and Equation (5) provided δmax. Table 6 lists all the kinetic parameters associated with the Chen–Hashimoto model.

caption.p: Kinetic parameters as a function of percentage TS concentration.

sec.p: Most of the derived kinetic parameters in Table 6 appear to be nominally affected by the change in feed % TS concentration. In some cases, the slight changes are readily explainable since they can be correlated to physical phenomena. For example, the drop in µmax is likely caused by overloading, since less effective microbial activity naturally occurs under higher-than-optimum feed conditions due to ‘overcrowding’. The large concentrations of feed solids used in this research generally explain the lower µmax and k values as compared to other researchers who have ascertained kinetic coefficients for the Chen–Hashimoto model and/or its modifications (Tosun et al., 2004; Vavilin et al., 2001). The kinetic values in this investigation are comparable, however, to those obtained in a study treating olive mill solid waste with a VS concentration in the 8 to 12% range (Borja et al., 2003). It is evident therefore that the choice of feed concentration influences the kinetic parameters of concern.

As indicated above, the group A runs were used to generate the relevant kinetic parameters (k, Yo, µmax) shown in Table 6. These kinetic coefficients were then used in Equation (2) to predict the CH4 production for the two group B runs. Figures 2 and 3 compare the model prediction for CH4 (Y) in L g
VS
feed
− 1
, with the actual CH4 production from runs 4 and 5, respectively. Although both figures indicate the model under-predicts the actual amount of gas (by an average of 16.5 ± 6.6%), it is reasonable to suggest that the Chen–Hashimoto model is a useful tool to predict the methane generation potential of anaerobic digesters treating OFMSW at mesophilic temperatures.

caption.p: Methane production as a function of % TS: model prediction vs. actual.
Methane production as a function of HRT: model prediction vs. actual.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This study revealed that two-stage anaerobic digestion of OFMSW was successful under the conditions investigated. In particular, the acidogenic reactors generated large amounts of VFAs and had a favorable VFA/alkalinity ratio. The VFA concentration increased with an increase in feed TS; however, it decreased at longer HRTs. The methane yield in the methanogenic reactors was affected in an inverse fashion (i.e. a decrease with an increase in feed TS and an increase at longer HRTs). Overall, the percentage TS and VS removals were well above the typical range for municipal digesters. Finally, a kinetic analysis suggested that the Chen–Hashimoto model can be used to predict the amount of methane generated from the digestion of OFMSW, even though it under-predicts the volume of gas expected.

ack.p: The authors would like to thank S. Padungthon for providing the background information for this study. We also wish to thank the staff at the Sanitary Engineering Laboratory, Mahidol University, Bangkok, Thailand for their excellent technical assistance.

fn.p: This research was supported by a grant (ESTM-S-04-01-M-001-2545) from the Centre for Environmental Health, Toxicology and Management of Chemicals (ETM) and the Science & Technology Post Education and Research Development Office (PERDO) of the Ministry of Education, Bangkok, Thailand to the Faculty of Public Health, Mahidol University, Bangkok, Thailand.
